summary: This document is an email chain between federal prosecutors discussing a New York Post article claiming Jeffrey Epstein received a lenient sentence due to cooperating on the Bear Stearns case. The prosecutors from the Bear Stearns case state they had never heard of Epstein and the Florida prosecutor shares their theory on how the rumor started. The email includes the text of the Page Six article detailing Epstein's release and alleged cooperation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the email discussion and NY Post article; described as a billionaire financier released early from prison after pleading guilty to procuring teenage girls for prostitution, and rumored to be cooperating with federal prosecutors.

persons.name: Ralph Cioffi
persons.role: Bear Stearns hedge fund manager, defendant
persons.context: Named in the NY Post article as one of the Bear Stearns hedge fund managers Epstein was allegedly helping prosecutors against; facing trial for misleading investors.

persons.name: Matthew Tannin
persons.role: Bear Stearns hedge fund manager, defendant
persons.context: Named in the NY Post article as one of the Bear Stearns hedge fund managers Epstein was allegedly helping prosecutors against; facing trial for misleading investors.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who negotiated his plea deal; the article states Epstein visited his offices daily during work release and gave him a new BMW.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned in the NY Post article as someone Epstein used to 'hobnob' with.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned in the NY Post article as someone Epstein used to 'hobnob' with.

persons.name: John Connolly
persons.context: Investigative reporter quoted in the NY Post article providing information about Epstein giving his lawyer a BMW.

persons.name: Nadia Marcinkova
persons.context: Described in the NY Post article as an 'assistant' who allegedly wrangled teen masseuses for Epstein and joined in sex play; noted to have visited Epstein in jail over 67 times.

connections.description: Goldberger is identified as Epstein's lawyer who negotiated his plea deal; Epstein reportedly visited his offices daily and gave him a new BMW.
The NY Post article alleges Epstein was helping prosecutors against Cioffi, who allegedly took Epstein for $67 million.
The NY Post article alleges Epstein was helping prosecutors against Tannin, who allegedly took Epstein for $67 million.
Marcinkova is described as Epstein's 'assistant' who allegedly procured teen masseuses and participated in sex acts; she visited him frequently in jail.
The article states Epstein used to 'hobnob' with Bill Clinton.
The article states Epstein used to 'hobnob' with Prince Andrew.
Both are Bear Stearns hedge fund managers jointly charged with misleading investors in their fund.

events.title: Epstein's Early Release from Prison
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was released six months early from his 18-month prison sentence in Florida.

events.title: Scheduled Trial for Bear Stearns Case
events.description: The trial for US v Cioffi & Tannin (the Bear Stearns hedge fund case) was scheduled to begin.

events.title: NY Post Article on Epstein's Cooperation
events.description: The New York Post published a Page Six article claiming Epstein received early release because he was cooperating with federal prosecutors on the Bear Stearns case.

locations: West Palm Beach, FL (500 S. Australian Ave, Suite 400 - AUSA office)
keyFacts: Federal prosecutors working on the Bear Stearns case (US v Cioffi & Tannin) had never heard of Jeffrey Epstein until reading a NY Post article claiming he was cooperating with them.

A New York Post article claimed Epstein was released early from prison because he was cooperating with federal prosecutors on the Bear Stearns hedge fund case, a claim the prosecutors directly refute.
Epstein was reportedly given work release, visiting his lawyer Jack Goldberger's office 12 hours a day, six days a week, during his incarceration.
The article details Epstein's properties: a Palm Beach mansion, Santa Fe ranch, the largest private house in Manhattan, and a private Bahamian island called 'St. Jeffs'.
Model Nadia Marcinkova, described as an 'assistant' who allegedly procured teens for Epstein, visited him over 67 times in jail according to records cited in the article.
